newsitem.title: FRANCE: Barry Callebaut says will use veg fat in chocolate.
newsitem.headline: Barry Callebaut says will use veg fat in chocolate.

text.p: Top chocolate maker and cocoa bean processor Barry Callebaut AG said on Tuesday it would supply its industrial clients with chocolate containing vegetable fats if they want it and if European rules allow it.
But the group ruled out changing the recipe of its own brand of gourmet chocolate to include non-cocoa fats.

"The position of Barry Callebaut is clear. If we have clients in the industry who want this chocolate, we will supply it. But in the gourmet sector where we are offering our own brand we will not put vegetable fats in chocolate," Benoit Villiers, the group's general manager for France, told a news conference.
"If it becomes legal, there will be requests (for chocolate containing vegetable fats) and our duty is to supply clients," he added.

The European Union has drafted a proposal that would allow member states the freedom to make chocolate containing up to five percent of non-cocoa vegetable fats, provided consumers are properly informed of the product's content.
Opponents say countries which use cocoa butter in chocolate may switch to these cheaper supplies, a development that would hit income in developing countries such as Ivory Coast, Ghana or Cameroon.

Barry Callebaut, the group formed by the merger of France's Cacao Barry and of Swiss Callebaut AG, is the world's largest cocoa bean processor and a major force in the finished chocolate and chocolate coatings market. It operates 19 plants worldwide, including three cocoa-bean processing plants in Ivory Coast.
